factoid: Princess Mary burst into tears.
Princess Mary said she did not know what was wrong with her that day.
Princess Mary told Pierre to forget what she had said.
Pierre's gaiety vanished completely.
Pierre anxiously questioned Princess Mary and asked her to speak fully and confide her grief.
Princess Mary repeated that she begged Pierre to forget what she had said.
Princess Mary repeated that she did not remember what she had said.
Princess Mary repeated that she had no trouble except the one Pierre knew of.
Princess Mary repeated that Prince Andrew's marriage threatened to cause a rupture between father and son.
Princess Mary asked Pierre if he had any news of the Rostóvs.
Princess Mary said she was told the Rostóvs are coming soon.
Princess Mary said she was also expecting Prince Andrew any day.
Princess Mary said she would like the Rostóvs to meet here.
Pierre asked how Prince Andrew now regards the matter.
Princess Mary shook her head.
Princess Mary said what is to be done.
Princess Mary said in a few months the year will be up.
Princess Mary said the thing is impossible.
Princess Mary said she only wished she could spare her brother the first moments.
Princess Mary wished the Rostóvs would come sooner.
Princess Mary hoped to be friends with the Rostóvs.
Princess Mary said she had known the Rostóvs a long time.
Princess Mary asked Pierre to tell her honestly the whole truth about what sort of girl the Rostóvs are and what he thinks of them.
Princess Mary said Prince Andrew is risking so much doing this against his father's will.
Pierre said he did not know how to answer her question.
Pierre said he really did not know what sort of girl the Rostóvs are.
Pierre said he could not analyze the Rostóvs at all.
Pierre said the Rostóvs are enchanting but he does not know what makes them so.
Princess Mary sighed, and the expression on her face said that she expected and feared that.
Princess Mary asked if the Rostóvs are clever.
Pierre considered the question.
Pierre said he thinks the Rostóvs are not clever, yet he is not sure.
Pierre said the Rostóvs do not deign to be clever.
Pierre said the Rostóvs are simply enchanting.
Princess Mary shook her head disapprovingly.
Princess Mary said she longed to like the Rostóvs.
Princess Mary told Pierre her plan to become intimate with her future sister-in-law as soon as the Rostóvs arrived.
Princess Mary told Pierre her plan to try to accustom Prince Andrew to her.
Borís had not succeeded in making a wealthy match in Petersburg.
Borís came to Moscow to try to make a wealthy match.
Borís wavered between the two richest heiresses, Julie and Princess Mary.
Princess Mary seemed more attractive to Borís than Julie.
Borís felt awkward about paying court to Princess Mary.
When they had last met on Prince Andrew's name day, Princess Mary answered at random all Borís's attempts to talk sentimentally.
Princess Mary did not listen to what Borís was saying.
Julie accepted Borís's attentions readily.
Julie was twenty-seven years old.
Julie became very wealthy after the death of her brothers.
Julie was now decidedly plain.
Julie thought herself not merely as good-looking as before but even far more attractive.
Julie's delusion was confirmed by her becoming a very wealthy heiress.
Julie's delusion was confirmed by the fact that the older she grew the less dangerous she became to men.
Julie's delusion was confirmed by the fact that men could associate with her and avail themselves of her suppers, soirees, and the animated company at her house without incurring any obligation.

A man who would have been afraid ten years before of going every day to the house when there was a girl of seventeen there, for fear of compromising her and committing himself, would now go boldly every day and treat her not as a marriageable girl but as a sexless acquaintance.
